DataElement.preferredName: Therapeutic Procedure Agent Chemotherapy Mercaptopurine Discontinue Yes No Not Applicable Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Question to indicate whether 6-mercaptopurine had to be discontinued for the patient

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Therapeutic Procedure Agent Chemotherapy Mercaptopurine Discontinue
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process._An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect._The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases._A thiopurine-derivative antimetabolite with antineoplastic and immunosuppressive activities.  Produced through the metabolism of mercaptopurine by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), mercaptopurine metabolites 6-thioguanosine-5'-phosphate (6-thioGMP) and 6-thioinosine monophosphate (T-IMP) inhibit nucleotide interconversions and de novo purine synthesis, thereby blocking the formation of purine nucleotides and inhibiting DNA synthesis.  This agent is also incorporated into DNA in the form of deoxythioguanosine, which results in the disruption of DNA replication. In addition, mercaptopurine is converted to 6-methylmercaptopurine ribonucleoside (MMPR) by 6-thiopurine methyltransferase; MMPRs are also potent inhibitors of de novo purine synthesis. (NCI04)_To stop or end, permanently or temporarily.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

Property.preferredDefinition: An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.:The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.:A thiopurine-derivative antimetabolite with antineoplastic and immunosuppressive activities.  Produced through the metabolism of mercaptopurine by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), mercaptopurine metabolites 6-thioguanosine-5'-phosphate (6-thioGMP) and 6-thioinosine monophosphate (T-IMP) inhibit nucleotide interconversions and de novo purine synthesis, thereby blocking the formation of purine nucleotides and inhibiting DNA synthesis.  This agent is also incorporated into DNA in the form of deoxythioguanosine, which results in the disruption of DNA replication. In addition, mercaptopurine is converted to 6-methylmercaptopurine ribonucleoside (MMPR) by 6-thiopurine methyltransferase; MMPRs are also potent inhibitors of de novo purine synthesis. (NCI04):To stop or end, permanently or temporarily.

Concepts.definition: An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.
The use of synthetic or naturally-occurring chemicals for the treatment of diseases.

A thiopurine-derivative antimetabolite with antineoplastic and immunosuppressive activities.  Produced through the metabolism of mercaptopurine by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), mercaptopurine metabolites 6-thioguanosine-5'-phosphate (6-thioGMP) and 6-thioinosine monophosphate (T-IMP) inhibit nucleotide interconversions and de novo purine synthesis, thereby blocking the formation of purine nucleotides and inhibiting DNA synthesis.  This agent is also incorporated into DNA in the form of deoxythioguanosine, which results in the disruption of DNA replication. In addition, mercaptopurine is converted to 6-methylmercaptopurine ribonucleoside (MMPR) by 6-thiopurine methyltransferase; MMPRs are also potent inhibitors of de novo purine synthesis. (NCI04)
To stop or end, permanently or temporarily.

DataElementConcept.origin: COG CRF:Children's Oncology Group Case Report Form

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of yes, no, or not applicable.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Did the patient require disco
ReferenceDocuments.description: Did the patient require discontinuation of 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 01
ReferenceDocuments.description: Did the patient require discontinuation of 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) at day 8 due to hepatic toxicity per protocol?
